angle.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, it is known that angle α = 130.0, then angle β = ()
Choices:
A:30°
B:40°
C:50°
D:65°
angle.new_question_description: Changed the given angle α from 130° to 120° while keeping the same diagram and geometric relationships.
angle.new_question: As shown in the figure, it is known that angle α = 120.0°, then angle β = ()  A. 30°  B. 60°  C. 45°  D. 90°
angle.new_answer_description: The right-angle mark indicates one segment is perpendicular, so β equals α minus 90°; thus β = 120° − 90° = 30°.
angle.check_answer_description: The slanted line and the horizontal line form a straight line at the top so α and the adjacent angle sum to 180°. Given α = 120°, the adjacent (corresponding) angle is 60°, which equals β by the right-angle and parallel-line relationships in the figure.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: At the top vertex the triangle angle is 90°. The given α is the external angle on the left, so the interior angle between the left leg and the horizontal is 180°−α = 50°. Along the straight horizontal line the interior left angle (50°), the top right angle (90°), and the interior right angle add to 180°, so the interior right angle = 180°−50°−90° = 40°, which equals β.

angle.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, it is known that OA = OB = OC, then the size of angle AOB is ()
Choices:
A:40°
B:50°
C:60°
D:70°
angle.new_question_description: The angle marked at C is increased from 30° to 40°; everything else (OA = OB = OC and the diagram) stays the same.
angle.new_question: {In the figure, OA = OB = OC and the angle at C (angle A C B) is 40°; what is the measure of angle AOB? Options: A. 80°; B. 100°; C. 60°; D. 40°}
angle.new_answer_description: Since OA = OB = OC, O is the circumcenter of triangle ABC. The central angle AOB subtends arc AB and equals twice the inscribed angle ACB. Thus angle AOB = 2 * 40° = 80°.
angle.check_answer_description: Since OA = OB = OC, O is the circumcenter of triangle ABC; the central angle AOB subtends arc AB, so ∠AOB = 2·∠ACB = 2·40° = 80°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: O is the circle center (OA=OB=OC), so ∠AOB is the central angle subtending arc AB and equals twice the inscribed angle ∠ACB. The figure shows ∠ACB = 30°, hence ∠AOB = 2×30° = 60°.

angle.orig_question:
\overrightarrow B D bisects \angle A B F. If m \angle F B C = 2 x + 25 and m \angle A B F = 10 x - 1, find m \angle D B F.
Choices:
A:25.5
B:50
C:54
D:64.5
angle.new_question_description: Change the algebraic expressions for m∠FBC and m∠ABF so their sum is 180°, then use the fact that BD bisects ∠ABF to find m∠DBF.
angle.new_question:
Given that ray BD bisects ∠ABF, m∠FBC = 4x + 20 and m∠ABF = 6x + 50, find m∠DBF.
A. 58
B. 52
C. 64
D. 49
angle.new_answer_description: Rays BA and BC are opposite, so ∠ABF + ∠FBC = 180°. Thus (6x + 50) + (4x + 20) = 180 → 10x + 70 = 180 → x = 11. Then m∠ABF = 6(11) + 50 = 116°. Since BD bisects ∠ABF, m∠DBF = 116° / 2 = 58°.
angle.check_answer_description: A, B, C are collinear so ∠ABF + ∠FBC = 180. Solve (6x+50)+(4x+20)=180 → 10x+70=180 → x=11. BD bisects ∠ABF so ∠DBF = (6x+50)/2 = 3x+25 = 3(11)+25 = 58°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: BA and BC are opposite rays so ∠ABF + ∠FBC = 180. Substitute: (10x−1)+(2x+25)=180 → 12x+24=180 → x=13. Then ∠ABF = 10(13)−1 =129°, and BD bisects ∠ABF so ∠DBF = 129/2 = 64.5°.

angle.orig_question: The airtraffic controller is communicating with a plane in flight approaching an airport for landing. The plane is 10369 metres above the ground and is still 23444 metres from the runway. If \theta ° is the angle at which the plane should approach, find \theta  to one decimal place.
angle.new_question_description: Increase the plane's altitude and slightly reduce its horizontal distance so the approach angle changes; compute the new approach angle to one decimal place.
angle.new_question: The plane is 12000 metres above the ground and is 22000 metres from the runway; if θ° is the approach angle (angle between the ground and the line to the plane), find θ to one decimal place.
angle.new_answer_description: θ = arctan(opposite/adjacent) = arctan(12000/22000) = arctan(0.5454545…) ≈ 28.7°.
angle.check_answer_description: Use tanθ = opposite/adjacent = 12000/22000 = 6/11 ≈ 0.545454; θ = arctan(0.545454) ≈ 28.6° (to one decimal place).
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Use tan(theta)=opposite/adjacent = 10369/23444 ≈ 0.4427, so theta = arctan(0.4427) ≈ 23.9°.

angle.orig_question:
angle AOD = 136.0, then the degree of angle C is ()
Choices:
A:44°
B:22°
C:46°
D:36°
angle.new_question_description: The central angle AOD is changed from 136° to 124°; ask for angle C in the same figure.
angle.new_question: {If angle AOD = 124°, then what is the degree measure of angle C? Options: A. 28°  B. 56°  C. 32°  D. 62°}
angle.new_answer_description: Angle C is half the supplement of the central angle AOD: angle C = (180° - 124°) / 2 = 56° / 2 = 28°.
angle.check_answer_description: OA and OB are endpoints of a diameter so ∠AOB = 180°. Given ∠AOD = 124°, so central ∠BOD = 180°−124° = 56°. Inscribed ∠C intercepts arc BD, so ∠C = 1/2·arcBD = 56°/2 = 28°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: OA and OB are opposite (diameter) so ∠BOD = 180° − ∠AOD = 44°. Angle at C is an inscribed angle subtending arc BD, so ∠C = 1/2·∠BOD = 22°.

angle.new_answer_description: In the configuration OBC equals 90° minus angle DAC (as in the original relation). Thus OBC = 90° − 34° = 56°.
angle.check_answer_description: In parallelogram ABCD (DA ∥ BC) the diagonal intersection O makes triangle symmetry so angle OBC equals angle between DA and AC, hence equals given 34°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Let BD and AC intersect at O. Triangles A D C and B O C are similar because ∠ADC = ∠BCO (vertical/parallel corresponding) and they share ∠ACD = ∠BCO, so corresponding angles give ∠OBC = ∠DAC. Hence ∠OBC = 28°.

angle.orig_question: Find \theta  to one decimal place.
angle.new_question_description: Change the plane's horizontal distance to 20000 m and its vertical height to 12000 m, then ask for the angle of elevation to the plane from the runway point.
angle.new_question: Find theta (angle of elevation) to one decimal place when the plane is 12000 m above the runway and 20000 m horizontally away.
angle.new_answer_description: Theta = arctan(vertical/horizontal) = arctan(12000/20000) = arctan(0.6). arctan(0.6) ≈ 30.9638°, so to one decimal place theta ≈ 31.0°.
angle.check_answer_description: Use tan(theta)=opposite/adjacent = 12000/20000 = 0.6, so theta = arctan(0.6) ≈ 30.9638°, rounded to one decimal place is 31.0°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Use tanθ = opposite/adjacent = 10369/23444; compute θ = arctan(10369/23444) ≈ arctan(0.4426) ≈ 23.9°.

angle.orig_question:
Place a ruler and a triangular plate as shown in the figure,then the degree of angle 2 is ()
Choices:
A:130°
B:140°
C:120°
D:125°
angle.new_question_description: The marked acute angle at the top is changed from 40° to 50°; ask for the resulting measure of angle 2 formed by the ruler and the triangle as in the figure.
angle.new_question:
If the small marked angle at the top is 50°, what is the measure of angle 2?
A. 140
B. 40
C. 130
D. 50
angle.new_answer_description: The ruler is perpendicular to the small right-angle mark at the triangle's apex, so angle 2 equals that 90° plus the given 50° (they form a straight-like configuration across the triangle), giving 90° + 50° = 140°.
angle.check_answer_description: The small marked angle (50°) and the right-angle marker show the bar is perpendicular to the short segment, so the angle between the bar and the left slanted side is 90°−50°=40°. That angle corresponds to angle 2 by the geometry of the intersecting lines, so angle 2 = 40°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Let the triangle apex be a right angle (90°). The ruler makes 40° with the left side, so it makes 90°−40°=50° with the right side. The angle labeled 2 is the exterior angle formed by the ruler and the base, which equals 90°+50°=140°.

A. 26
B. 50
C. 58
D. 32
angle.new_answer_description: Because EC is parallel to AB, the angle formed at the intersection with BE corresponding to ∠2 is congruent to ∠5 (corresponding angles). Therefore ∠5 has the same measure as ∠2, which is 50.

angle.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, angle AOB = 50.0, then the degree of the angle of circumference angle ACB is ()
Choices:
A:50°

angle.new_question_description: Changed the central angle AOB from 50° to 120° and ask for the inscribed angle ACB that subtends the same chord AB.
angle.new_question: As shown in the figure, angle AOB = 120°, then what is the degree measure of the inscribed angle ACB? A. 30°   B. 60°   C. 90°   D. 120°
angle.new_answer_description: An inscribed angle that subtends the same chord AB is half the central angle AOB subtending that chord, so ACB = 120° / 2 = 60°.
angle.check_answer_description: The central angle AOB measures the arc AB as 120°. An inscribed angle that subtends the same arc equals half the central angle, so ACB = 120°/2 = 60°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Central angle AOB subtends arc AB; inscribed angle ACB subtending the same arc equals half the central angle, so ACB = 50°/2 = 25°.

angle.orig_question: Given the diagram shown, if the bearing of the clearing from the town is a°, find a to the nearest degree.
angle.new_question_description: Change the eastward distance from the north line to the clearing from 5.9 km to 6.4 km while keeping the northward distance 3.2 km, then ask for the bearing from the town to the clearing.
angle.new_question: Given the diagram shown, if the clearing is 6.4 km east of the north line and 3.2 km north of the town, find the bearing a° of the clearing from the town to the nearest degree.
angle.new_answer_description: The bearing a is the clockwise angle from north to the line joining the town to the clearing. Tan(a) = east/north = 6.4/3.2 = 2, so a = arctan(2) ≈ 63.4349°, which rounds to 63°.
angle.check_answer_description: Place town at origin, clearing at (6.4 east, 3.2 north); bearing from north = arctan(east/north) = arctan(6.4/3.2)=arctan(2) ≈ 63.43°, so a ≈ 63°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Coordinates: town (0,0), clearing (5.9,3.2). Bearing from north clockwise = arctan(east/north) = arctan(5.9/3.2) ≈ 61.5°, so a ≈ 62°.

angle.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, AB parallel CD, angle B = 20.0, angle D = 60.0, then the degree of angle BED is ()
Choices:

B:80°

angle.new_question: As shown in the figure, AB ∥ CD, angle B = 30°, angle D = 60°; what is the measure of angle BED? A. 90°  B. 30°  C. 60°  D. 120°
angle.new_answer_description: BE makes an angle of 30° below the top parallel and DE makes an angle of 60° above the bottom parallel; the interior angle between BE and DE equals 180° − (30° + 60°) = 90°.
angle.check_answer_description: Angle at B with BA gives BE direction 150° from right; angle at D gives DE direction 120° from right. Reversing directions to get rays EB (330°) and ED (300°) at E, the angle between them is |330°−300°|=30°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Let the angles that BE and DE make with the parallel lines equal the given angles at B and D (20° and 60°). The angle between the two transversals at E is the exterior angle sum: angle BED = 180° - (angle B + angle D) = 180° - (20° + 60°) = 100°.

angle.orig_question:
Find the measure of \angle A F B.
Choices:
A:72
B:108
C:120
D:144
angle.new_question_description: Change the numeric central angle at the top to 84°, change the right-sector expression to (3a + 6)°, change the bottom-left sector expression to (2a - 6)°, and label angle AFB as (a + 30)°; ask for the measure of angle AFB.
angle.new_question: If the four central angles around point F are 84°, (3a + 6)°, (2a - 6)°, and (a + 30)°, what is the measure of angle AFB? A. 71°  B. 76°  C. 84°  D. 129°
angle.new_answer_description: The four central angles sum to 360°, so (a + 30) + 84 + (3a + 6) + (2a - 6) = 360. Combine like terms: 6a + 114 = 360, so 6a = 246 and a = 41. Then angle AFB = a + 30 = 41 + 30 = 71°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Assume the four central angles at F (∠BFC=72°, ∠CFD=(4a−1)°, ∠DFA=(2a−5)°, and ∠AFB) sum to 360°. So ∠AFB + 72 + (4a−1) + (2a−5) = 360. Combine terms: ∠AFB + 6a + 66 = 360, so ∠AFB = 294 − 6a. Solve for a by using the given labeled central angles must be positive and integer; choosing a = 29 gives (4a−1)=115° and (2a−5)=53°, all valid, and yields ∠AFB = 294 − 6·29 = 120°.

angle.orig_question:
Consider the points on the diagram P, M and S where S denotes the south cardinal point. Angle PMS is 37°.

Using the diagram, find the true bearing of P from M.
angle.new_question_description: Change the given angle PMS from 37° to 52° and ask for the true bearing of P from M.
angle.new_question: Consider the points on the diagram P, M and S where S denotes the south cardinal point. Angle PMS is 52°. Using the diagram, find the true bearing of P from M.
angle.new_answer_description: The ray MS points to 180° (south). The angle between MP and MS is 52°, so MP is 52° anticlockwise from south, which gives a bearing of 180° + 52° = 232°.
angle.check_answer_description: Angle PMS is the angle between MP and the south line MS (vertex at M) = 52°. MP is 52° west of south, so its bearing from north clockwise = 180° + 52° = 232°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: At M the line MS points due south. The bearing of P from M is measured clockwise from north. Since angle PMS = 37° is the acute angle between PM and the south direction, PM lies 37° anticlockwise from south, i.e. 37° short of a full clockwise turn from north. Thus the true bearing = 360° − 37° = 323°.

angle.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, points A, B, and C are on circle O, angle ABO = 40.0, angle ACO = 30.0, then the degree of angle BOC is ()
Choices:
A:60°
B:70°
C:120°
D:140°
angle.new_question_description: Change the given angle measures at points B and C to new values (angle ABO = 25° and angle ACO = 15°) and ask for the central angle BOC.
angle.new_question:
As shown in the figure, points A, B, and C are on circle O, angle ABO = 25, angle ACO = 15, then the degree of angle BOC is ()
A. 80°
B. 20°
C. 40°
D. 100°
angle.new_answer_description: In isosceles triangles AOB and AOC (OA = OB = OC), ∠AOB = 180° − 2·∠ABO and ∠AOC = 180° − 2·∠ACO. The three central angles around O sum to 360°, so ∠BOC = 360° − ∠AOB − ∠AOC = 2(∠ABO + ∠ACO) = 2(25° + 15°) = 80°.
angle.check_answer_description: In isosceles triangle ABO (OA=OB) angles OAB and ABO are equal, so AOB = 180−2·25 = 130°. In isosceles triangle ACO (OA=OC) AOC = 180−2·15 = 150°. Thus BOC = AOC−AOB = 150−130 = 20°.
angle.orig_answer_description_check: In isosceles triangles OBA and OCA (OA=OB=OC), angle OAB = angle ABO = 40°, so central angle AOB = 180°−2×40° = 100°. Similarly angle AOC = 180°−2×30° = 120°. Point A lies between B and C on the circle, so the minor central angle BOC = 360°−(AOB+AOC) = 360°−(100°+120°) = 140°.

angle.new_answer_description: For angle X, the opposite side is VW = 72 and the hypotenuse is VX = 75, so sin X = 72/75 = 0.96.
angle.check_answer_description: Right triangle with hypotenuse VX=75 and side opposite angle X is WV=72, so sin X = 72/75 = 0.96 (to nearest hundredth).
angle.orig_answer_description_check: Angle X has adjacent side WX = 21 and hypotenuse VX = 75, so cos X = 21/75 = 0.28.

angle.new_answer_description: Angle 4 (between EC and BC) equals the angle between AB and BC because EC ∥ AB. The angle between AB and BC is the sum of the angle between AB and BE (47°) and the angle between BE and BC (30°). So angle 4 = 47° + 30° = 77°.

Round your answer to two decimal places.
angle.new_question_description: The rectangle's bottom side length is changed from 3 to 4 while the diagonal BC remains 5; find the angle x at corner B between the top side and the diagonal.
angle.new_question: In the diagram, the bottom side AC is 4, the diagonal BC is 5, and AB is perpendicular to AC; find x (the angle between the top horizontal and diagonal BC) in degrees, rounded to two decimal places.
angle.new_answer_description: Place A=(0,0), B=(0,h), C=(4,0). From BC = 5: h^2 + 4^2 = 5^2 → h = 3. The diagonal from B to C has vertical drop 3 and horizontal run 4, so the angle below the horizontal is arctan(3/4). Thus x = arctan(3/4) ≈ 36.87°.

angle.new_answer_description: The two rays from B are perpendicular (right angle mark), so angle1 and the acute angle made by the right-hand ray with the lower line sum to 90°. That acute angle is corresponding (alternate interior) to angle2 on the upper parallel line, so angle1 + angle2 = 90°. Therefore angle2 = 90° − 40° = 50°.

length.new_question: {In the figure, BA is tangent to circle O at A, OB meets the circle at C, angle B = 30° and AB = 3; find the length of BC. Options: A. √3  B. 1.5  C. 2  D. 3}
length.new_answer_description: Let AB = s and angle B = θ. With OA ⟂ BA and O at distance r = s·tanθ from the tangent, BC = sqrt(s^2 + r^2) - r = s(√(1+tan^2θ) - tanθ) = s(secθ - tanθ). For s = 3 and θ = 30°, sec30 = 2/√3 and tan30 = 1/√3, so BC = 3((2/√3) - (1/√3)) = 3/√3 = √3.
length.check_answer_description: Let angle ABC =30°. By the tangent-chord theorem angle between tangent BA and chord AC equals angle ABC, so angle BAC =30°. In triangle ABC angles at A and B are 30°, so angle C =120°. Use Law of Sines: BC/sin30 = AB/sin120 => BC = AB*(sin30/sin120)=3*(1/2)/(√3/2)=3/√3=√3.
length.orig_answer_description_check: Place center O at origin and let OB = d, radius = r. Tangent length AB = sqrt(d^2 - r^2) = 2, so d^2 - r^2 = 4. Let A be at angle φ on the circle; tangent through A meets OB at B, giving AB = r|tanφ| = 2, so |tanφ| = 2/r. The angle between BA and BC is 45°, which yields d = r( sinφ + cosφ ). Also from geometry d = r cos2φ / cosφ. Equating gives sinφ( sinφ + cosφ ) = 0, so sinφ + cosφ = 0 and thus |tanφ| = 1, hence r = 2. Then d^2 = r^2 + 4 = 8 so d = 2√2 and BC = d - r = 2√2 - 2.

length.new_answer_description: For the 30° angle, cos30° = adjacent/hypotenuse = 1/x. Since cos30° = √3/2, we have √3/2 = 1/x, so x = 1 / (√3/2) = 2/√3 = 2√3/3 after rationalizing the denominator.
length.check_answer_description: Right triangle with angles 30°-60°-90°; base (adjacent to 30°) = (√3/2)x, so x = 2/√3 = 2√3/3 after rationalizing.
length.orig_answer_description_check: Right triangle with angles 30°-60°-90°. The base (adjacent to 30°) = √3 equals (√3/2)·x, so (√3/2)x = √3 and x = √3·2/√3 = 2.

length.check_answer_description: In a 30-60-90 right triangle the side opposite 30° = hypotenuse/2. If that side = 28 then hypotenuse = 56; side opposite 60° = (sqrt(3)/2)*hypotenuse = 56*(√3/2) = 28√3.
length.orig_answer_description_check: Identify triangle as 30°-60°-90° with side opposite 30° equal to 21, so the side opposite 60° is 21√3; hence y = 21√3.

length.orig_question:
m \angle Q L M = 2 x^ { 2 } - 10, m \angle Q P M = 8 x, and M P = 10. Find the perimeter of L M P Q.
Choices:
A:10
B:40
C:70
D:140
length.new_question_description: Changed the length of segment MP from 10 to 12 (keeping the same angle expressions) so the figure is still a rhombus but with a different side length.
length.new_question: {m∠QLM = 2x^2 - 10, m∠QPM = 8x, and MP = 12. Find the perimeter of L M P Q.} A. 36  B. 60  C. 48  D. 52
length.new_answer_description: The figure is a rhombus so all four sides are equal; hence each side equals MP = 12. The perimeter is 4 × 12 = 48.
length.check_answer_description: Angles QLM and QPM are congruent (parallel opposite angles), so 2x^2 - 10 = 8x. Solve: 2x^2 - 8x - 10 = 0 → x^2 -4x -5 =0 → x=5. Then MP = 12 and in this parallelogram all sides equal (given shape), so each side =12; perimeter = 4·12 = 48.
length.orig_answer_description_check: Set m∠QLM = m∠QPM because they are opposite angles in parallelogram LMPQ, so 2x^2−10 = 8x. Solve: 2x^2−8x−10=0 ⇒ x^2−4x−5=0 ⇒ x=5. Given MP=10 and opposite sides of a parallelogram are equal, QL=10. The diagram is a rhombus so all four sides equal 10, thus perimeter = 4·10 = 40.

length.orig_question:
Consider the sector below.

Calculate the perimeter. Round your answer to two decimal places.
length.new_question_description: The central angle is changed from 237° to 210° while the radius remains 80.2 mm; compute the new perimeter of the sector.
length.new_question: Consider the sector below with radius 80.2 mm and central angle 210°; calculate the perimeter and round your answer to two decimal places.
length.new_answer_description: Perimeter = sum of two radii plus arc length = 2r + rθ (θ in radians). Convert 210° to radians: θ = 210° × π/180 = 7π/6 ≈ 3.665191. Arc length = 80.2 × 3.665191 ≈ 293.95. Add 2r = 160.4 to get perimeter ≈ 160.4 + 293.95 = 454.35.
length.orig_answer_description_check: Perimeter = 2r + arc length. Convert angle to radians: θ = 237° = 79π/60 ≈ 4.136423 rad. Arc = rθ = 80.2×4.136423 ≈ 331.7411 mm. Add two radii: 2×80.2 = 160.4 mm. Total = 160.4 + 331.7411 ≈ 492.1411 mm, round to two decimals.

applied.orig_question:
After filling some oil in a cylindrical oil tank, the maximum depth of oil is ()

A:40cm
B:60cm
C:80cm
D:100cm
applied.new_question_description: The question is changed to ask for the depth of the oil measured from the bottom of the cylindrical tank (instead of the distance from the top).
applied.new_question: {In the same figure (circle diameter 200, chord length 160), what is the depth of the oil measured from the bottom of the tank to the oil surface? A. 40  B. 60  C. 160  D. 80}
applied.new_answer_description: Radius r = 200/2 = 100. Half the chord = 160/2 = 80. Distance from center to chord = sqrt(r^2 - 80^2) = sqrt(10000 - 6400) = 60. Depth from bottom = r + (distance from center to chord) = 100 + 60 = 160.
applied.check_answer_description: Radius R = 100. For a chord length l = 160, 160 = 2√(R^2 - d^2) so √(100^2 - d^2)=80 ⇒ d^2=3600 ⇒ d=60. The chord is 60 below the center; depth from bottom = R - d = 100 - 60 = 40.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Let radius R = 100 cm (diameter 200). For a chord of length 160, 160 = 2√(R^2 - d^2) so √(10000 - d^2)=80 → d^2=3600 → d=60 cm (distance from center to chord). Depth from bottom = R - (−R + d)? More simply: bottom is 100 cm below center, chord is 60 cm below center, so depth = 100−60 = 40 cm.

applied.new_answer_description: From the graph Justin's distance grows 25 units per time (slope = 125/5 = 25) and Oliver's grows 35 units per time (slope = 175/5 = 35). After 3 time units Justin has traveled 25*3 = 75 and Oliver 35*3 = 105. The difference is 105 - 75 = 30.
applied.check_answer_description: Oliver's slope = 175/5 = 35 units/time and Justin's slope = 125/5 = 25 units/time; after 3 units Oliver = 35×3 = 105 and Justin = 25×3 = 75, so Oliver has gone 105−75 = 30 more units.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Both lines pass through the origin; compare slopes. Justin goes from 0 to 125 in 5 time units (slope 25), Oliver goes from 0 to 175 in 5 time units (slope 35), so Oliver's slope is greater and he is faster.

State the coordinates of the center of the cake in the form $(a, b)$.
applied.new_question_description: Change the task from locating the center to writing the equation of the largest ellipse that fits inside the given rectangle (so semi-axes match half the rectangle's width and height).
applied.new_question: What is the equation of the largest ellipse (in standard form) centered inside the rectangular box shown?
applied.new_answer_description: The rectangle spans from x=0 to x=40 (width 40) and y=0 to y=20 (height 20), so the ellipse center is at (20,10) with semi-major and semi-minor axes a=20 and b=10. The standard form is (x-20)^2/20^2 + (y-10)^2/10^2 = 1.
applied.check_answer_description: The largest ellipse centered in the rectangle has semi-axes equal to half the rectangle's width and height. The rectangle corners are x=10 and x=40 (width 30) and y=0 and y=20 (height 20), so a=15 and b=10 and center is ((10+40)/2,(0+20)/2)=(25,10). Thus (x-25)^2/15^2+(y-10)^2/10^2=1.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: The largest ellipse that fits in a rectangle is centered at the rectangle's midpoint; reading the rectangle's midpoints from the grid gives center at x=20 and y=10.

applied.new_question: {At approximately what times t (in minutes after noon) do the two airplanes have the same height? Options: A. {0, 60, 100}  B. {80, 95}  C. {20, 40, 100}  D. {0, 95}}
applied.new_answer_description: Read the graph and identify points where the blue and pink curves cross. They coincide at the origin (t ≈ 0 minutes), once when both are at about 10,000 m near t ≈ 60 minutes, and again when both are at about 11,000 m near t ≈ 100 minutes.
applied.check_answer_description: Read horizontal segments: f = 10000 ft from t = 60 to 100, g = 10000 ft from t = 80 to 95, so their heights coincide for the overlap, i.e. from about t = 80 to t = 95 minutes after noon.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: The graphs plot heights of two airplanes versus time, so an intersection point is a time when the two height values are equal; mathematically these are the t-values satisfying f(t)=g(t).

applied.new_question:
Ashlynn models the temperature C of hot tea by C = 20 + 20·0.88^T and wanted to graph the relationship over the first hour (0 ≤ T ≤ 60). What mistake did she make when drawing the graph?
A. She graphed only 0–30 minutes instead of 0–60 minutes.
B. She plotted the temperature axis in Fahrenheit instead of Celsius.
C. She drew the curve increasing instead of decreasing, showing exponential growth.
D. She used T in seconds rather than minutes, compressing the time scale.
applied.new_answer_description: The graph only displays time up to 30 minutes while the requested domain is 0–60 minutes, so the x-axis scale/range is inappropriate for the specified interval.
applied.check_answer_description: The model gives C(0)=40 and decays toward 20 over 60 minutes. The plotted curve shows the correct shape but the x-axis only extends to about 30 minutes, so the graph stops halfway through the requested domain (0 ≤ T ≤ 60).
applied.orig_answer_description_check: The model gives C(0)=40 and C(30)=20+20(0.88)^30 ≈20.43, so the graph should show time only from 0 to 30 minutes. Ashlynn's x-axis extends with an arrow beyond the 30-minute range and the tick spacing compresses the first 30 minutes, so the x-scale is inappropriate for the requested first half hour. The axes are labeled, and the y-values shown (about 40 down to ~20) match the model, so the main error is the x-axis scale.

applied.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, the two street lamps A and B are separated by 30.0. One night, when Xiaogang went straight 25.0 from the bottom of street lamp A to the bottom of street lamp B, he found that the top of his figure just touched the bottom of street lamp B. Choices:

B:8米
C:7米

applied.new_question_description: Change the separation between the two street lamps to 36 and have Xiaogang walk 24 from the bottom of the left lamp toward the right lamp before his head just touches the line from the top of the left lamp to the base of the right lamp; ask for the lamp height.
applied.new_question: {Two identical street lamps are 36 apart. Xiaogang, height 1.5, stands 24 from the bottom of the left lamp (thus 12 from the right lamp) and finds that the line from the top of the left lamp to the base of the right lamp passes exactly through the top of his head; what is the height of each street lamp? Options: A. 3 B. 4.5 C. 6 D. 9}
applied.new_answer_description: The line from (0,H) to (36,0) has height at x=24 equal to H*(1 - 24/36)=H/3, which equals Xiaogang's height 1.5. Thus H/3 = 1.5, so H = 1.5 * 3 = 4.5.
applied.check_answer_description: Place left lamp at x=0 with height H and right lamp at x=36. Line from (0,H) to (36,0) has y = H(1 - x/36). At Xiaogang's position x=24 this gives y = H(1 - 24/36) = H/3, which equals his head height 1.5. So H/3 = 1.5 and H = 4.5.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Let lamp A height = H. Line from top of A to base of B has slope -H/30. At x=25 its height = H - (H/30)*25 = H(1 - 25/30) = H*(5/30)=H/6, which equals Xiaogang's height 1.5. So H/6=1.5 → H=9.

As shown in the figure, the student Xiao Li whose height is 1.6 wants to measure the height of the school's flagpole. When he stands at C, the shadow of the top of his head coincides with the shadow of the top of the flagpole, and AC = 2.0, BC = 8.0, then the height of the flagpole is ()

applied.new_question_description: Change the student's height and the distances AC and BC to new values while keeping the same shadow-coincidence setup.
applied.new_question: As shown in the figure, the student Xiao Li whose height is 1.5 m wants to measure the height of the school's flagpole. A. 6 m  B. 4 m  C. 8 m  D. 9 m
applied.new_answer_description: The tip of the shadow is at A, so distance from pole to shadow tip AB = AC + BC = 3.0 + 9.0 = 12. By similar triangles, flagpole height / 12 = student height / 3.0, so flagpole height = 12 * (1.5 / 3.0) = 12 * 0.5 = 6.
applied.check_answer_description: Shadows from the same sun make similar triangles: height_person/AC = height_pole/AB. Here AB = AC+BC = 3.0+9.0 =12.0, so height_pole = 1.5*(12.0/3.0) = 1.5*4 = 6.0 m.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Similar triangles: top of pole, top of head and sun are collinear, shadow point is at A. Student height 1.6 over AC=2 equals pole height h over AB=AC+BC=2+8=10, so h = 1.6*(10/2)=8.

applied.orig_question: Find the value of h to the nearest metre.
applied.new_question_description: Change the middle observer's angle of elevation from 22° to 24° while keeping the 29 m separation and the left observer's 10° angle the same.
applied.new_question: Using the same diagram but with the nearer observer measuring the tower's angle of elevation as 24° (the farther observer measures 10°) and the two observers 29 m apart, find the height h of the tower to the nearest metre.
applied.new_answer_description: Let x be the horizontal distance from the nearer observer to the tower. Then tan24° = h/x and tan10° = h/(x+29). Substitute x = h/tan24° into the second equation: tan10° = h/(h/tan24° + 29). Solve for h: h = 29*tan10° / (1 - tan10°/tan24°). Compute with tan10° ≈ 0.176326 and tan24° ≈ 0.445229 gives h ≈ 8.47, so to the nearest metre h = 8.
applied.check_answer_description: Let d be distance from nearer observer to tower. Then h = d·tan24° and h = (d+29)·tan10°. Equate: d(tan24°−tan10°)=29·tan10°, so d=29·tan10°/(tan24°−tan10°)≈19.02 m. Then h=d·tan24°≈19.02·0.44523≈8.47 m → 8 m (nearest metre).
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Let x be distance from the second person to the tower. From the diagram h = x·tan22° and also h = (x+29)·tan10°. Equate: x·tan22° = (x+29)·tan10°. Solve x = 29·tan10°/(tan22°−tan10°) ≈ 22.47 m. Then h = x·tan22° ≈ 9.08 m, so h ≈ 9 m.

applied.orig_question:

Hence find BC, the distance between the two poles in metres.

Round your answer to one decimal place.
applied.new_question_description: Change adds the angle of elevation to the top of the shorter pole (Pole 1) so both angles to the two poles from point A are given; compute the horizontal separation between the poles.
applied.new_question: From point A the angle of elevation to the top of Pole 1 (height 8 m) is 32° and to the top of Pole 2 (height 25 m) is 57°; find BC, the horizontal distance between the two poles, to one decimal place.
applied.new_answer_description: Let AB = x and AC = y. Then x = 8 / tan(32°) and y = 25 / tan(57°). Compute x ≈ 8 / 0.6249 ≈ 12.806 and y ≈ 25 / 1.5399 ≈ 16.240. The distance BC = y - x ≈ 16.240 - 12.806 = 3.434, which rounds to 3.4 (to one decimal place).
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Use horizontal distances from A to pole bases: AB = 8 / tan(32°) and AC = 25 / tan(57°). The distance between poles BC = AC − AB. Compute AC = 25 / tan57° ≈ 16.7? (use tan57° ≈ 1.5399 gives 25/1.5399 ≈ 16.24). Compute AB = 8 / tan32° (tan32° ≈ 0.6249 gives 8/0.6249 ≈ 12.81). Subtract: BC ≈ 16.24 − 12.81 = 3.43, rounded to one decimal = 3.4 m.

applied.orig_question:

applied.new_answer_description: Set 5x - x^2 = (3x - 0.5x^2) + 1. Rearranging gives -x^2 +5x -3x +0.5x^2 -1 = 0 → -0.5x^2 +2x -1 = 0. Multiply by -2: x^2 -4x +2 = 0. Solve: x = (4 ± √(16-8))/2 = 2 ± √2. The larger root is 2 + √2 ≈ 3.414, which rounds to 3.5 cm.
applied.check_answer_description: Set 5x - x^2 = (3x - 0.5x^2) + 1, rearrange to -0.5x^2 + 2x -1 = 0 ⇒ x^2 -4x +2 =0, solve x = 2 ± √2; the solution >1 is 2+√2 ≈ 3.414, rounded to nearest 0.5 is 3.5.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Set 5x - x^2 = 3x - 0.5x^2. Rearranging gives -0.5x^2 + 2x = 0 → x( x - 4 ) = 0, so x = 0 or x = 4; the other rainfall amount is 4 cm.

As shown in the figure, a student saw a tree by the lake. He visually observed that the distance between himself and the tree is 20.0, and the reflection of the top of the tree in the water is 5.0 far away from him. The student's height is 1.7, and the height of the tree is ( ).

applied.new_question: {A student 1.6 tall sees a tree by a lake; the horizontal distance from the student to the tree is 24 and the reflection of the top of the tree in the water appears 6 away from the student. What is the height of the tree? Options: A. 1.6 B. 3.2 C. 4.8 D. 6.4}
applied.new_answer_description: Using similar triangles: the line of sight to the real top and to its reflected image forms similar triangles with heights H (tree) and 1.6 (student). The ratio of heights equals the ratio of horizontal segments: H / 1.6 = (distance to tree − distance to reflection) / (distance to reflection) = (24 − 6) / 6 = 18 / 6 = 3. Thus H = 1.6 × 3 = 4.8.
applied.check_answer_description: Reflect the student's eye across the water to (0,-1.6). Line from tree top (24,H) to (0,-1.6) crosses water level y=0 at x = 1.6 / slope, with slope = (H+1.6)/24. Set this intersection x = 6: 1.6*24/(H+1.6)=6. Solve: H+1.6=38.4/6=6.4, so H=4.8.
applied.orig_answer_description_check: Let student eye at height 1.7 (x=0), water surface y=0, tree top at (20, H) and its image at (20, -H). The ray from the eye to the water strike point P at x=5 has slope (0-1.7)/(5-0)= -1.7/5. Extending that line to x=20 gives y = 1.7 + (-1.7/5)*20 = -5.1, so the image y = -H = -5.1 and H = 5.1.

area.orig_question:
A triangle with an acute angle of 30 degrees is within a circle, which forms the shaded region. Find the area of the shaded region. 
Choices:
A:35.2
B:43.2
C:53.5
D:56.9
area.new_question_description: The triangle's labeled side length is changed from 5 to 6 while the acute angle remains 30°, so the whole figure is uniformly scaled up; find the new shaded area.
area.new_question: {A triangle with an acute angle of 30 degrees is within a circle, matching the given figure but with the side labeled 6 instead of 5; find the area of the shaded region. Options: A. 36π - 18√3; B. 81.9; C. 54π - 27√3; D. 72π - 9√3}
area.new_answer_description: Scaling the figure by factor 6/5 multiplies all areas by (6/5)^2 = 1.44. The original shaded area was 56.9, so the new shaded area = 56.9 * 1.44 = 81.936, rounded to one decimal place is 81.9.
area.check_answer_description: Triangle is right with acute angle 30°, so it is a 30-60-90 triangle. The side given (6) is the short leg (opposite 30°), so the hypotenuse (diameter) is 12 and the circle radius r=6. Circle area = πr^2 = 36π. Triangle area = (1/2)*(short leg)*(long leg) = (1/2)*6*(6√3)=18√3. Shaded area = circle area − triangle area = 36π − 18√3.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Let AB be the diameter of the circle, O the center and C the upper point such that ∠COB = 30°. Coordinates: A(-R,0), B(R,0), C(R cos30°, R sin30°). Given AC = 5 so AC = R*sqrt(2+√3) = 5, hence R = 5/√(2+√3) and R^2 = 25/(2+√3) ≈ 6.698. Circle area = πR^2. Triangle ABC has base AB = 2R and height = y_C = R/2, so triangle area = (1/2)*(2R)*(R/2) = R^2/2. Shaded region = circle area − triangle area = R^2(π − 1/2) = 25(π − 1/2)/(2+√3) ≈ 17.70.

area.orig_question:
Consider the solid pictured and answer the following:

Hence what is the total surface area? The length is 24 cm.

Give your answer to the nearest two decimal places.
area.new_question_description: Increase the cylinder's length from 24 cm to 30 cm while keeping the inner and outer radii the same.
area.new_question: For the hollow cylindrical solid shown (inner radius 10 cm, outer radius 11 cm), if the length is 30 cm what is the total surface area? Give your answer to two decimal places.
area.new_answer_description: Total surface area = outer curved area + inner curved area + area of two annular ends = 2πh(r_o + r_i) + 2π(r_o^2 - r_i^2). With r_o=11, r_i=10, h=30 this is 2π·30·(11+10)+2π(11^2-10^2)=1302π ≈ 4090.35.
area.check_answer_description: Total surface area = outer lateral + inner lateral + 2 annular ends = 2πR L + 2πr L + 2π(R^2−r^2). With R=11, r=10, L=30 this is 2π[30(11+10)+(121−100)]=1302π ≈ 4090.35 cm^2.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Compute outer and inner lateral areas 2πRL and 2πrL and add areas of two annular ends 2·π(R^2−r^2). With R=11, r=10, L=24: total =2π[24(11+10)+(11^2−10^2)]=2π(504+21)=1050π ≈ 3298.67.

area.orig_question:

area.new_question:

area.new_answer_description: If π·l·w/4 = 9π then l·w = 36, the rectangle area. The ellipse area is 9π ≈ 28.274. The unshaded area = 36 − 9π ≈ 7.726, which rounds to 8.
area.check_answer_description: Area of ellipse = π·l·w/4 = 9π so l·w =36; rectangle ABCD area = l·w =36; unshaded area = rectangle − ellipse = 36 − 9π ≈ 7.7257, rounded to nearest whole number = 8.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Ellipse area = π*(l/2)*(w/2)=π·l·w/4 = 7π, so l·w/4 =7 ⇒ l·w =28. Rectangle area =28; unshaded area = rectangle − shaded = 28 − 7π ≈ 6.009, which rounds to 6.

area.new_question_description: Change the cone's vertical height from 4.0 to 3.0 while keeping the slant (generatrix) at 5.0, so the base radius and area change accordingly.
area.new_question: {In the figure, the cone's slant length is 5.0 and its vertical height is 3.0; what is the area of the cone's base? A. 25π  B. 16π  C. 9π  D. 12π}
area.new_answer_description: Radius r = sqrt(slnt^2 - height^2) = sqrt(5^2 - 3^2) = sqrt(25 - 9) = 4. Base area = πr^2 = π·4^2 = 16π.
area.check_answer_description: Use r = sqrt(l^2 - h^2) = sqrt(5^2 - 3^2) = 4, then base area = πr^2 = π(4^2) = 16π.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Use Pythagoras on slant height 5 and height 4 to get base radius r = sqrt(5^2-4^2)=3, then base area = πr^2 = 9π.

area.orig_question: Find the surface area of this prism. The thickness of the prism is 3cm.
area.new_question_description: Increase the prism's thickness (depth) from 3 cm to 4 cm and ask for the new surface area.
area.new_question: Find the surface area of this prism. The thickness of the prism is 4cm.
area.new_answer_description: Compute each exposed face. Front face splits into 13×8 and 4×16 => 104+64=168; back face the same => 168. Tops: 13×4 + 4×4 = 52+16 = 68. Bottom: 17×4 = 68. Ends: left 8×4 = 32, right 16×4 = 64 => 96. Vertical step face: height difference 8 × depth 4 = 32. Sum all: 168+168+68+68+96+32 = 600.
area.check_answer_description: Model the shape as two rectangular prisms joined: lower prism 17×8×4 and upper prism 4×8×4 sitting on the right of the lower. Compute SA of each and subtract the two internal contact faces (area 4×4 each): SA = 2(17·4+17·8+4·8) + 2(4·4+4·8+4·8) − 2(4·4) = 472 + 160 − 32 = 600 cm².
area.orig_answer_description_check: Compute cross-section area as full 17×16 rectangle minus the removed 13×8 notch: A = 272−104 = 168 cm². Cross-section perimeter = 17 +16 +4 +8 +13 +8 = 66 cm. Surface area = 2A + P·thickness = 2·168 + 66·3 = 336 + 198 = 534 cm².

area.new_answer_description: Lateral area of a half-cylinder = (1/2) × (circumference of full circle) × length = π r × L. With r = 0.92 and L = 3.10, area = π × 0.92 × 3.10 = π × 2.852 = 8.9578..., which rounds to 8.96.
area.check_answer_description: Lateral area of a half-cylinder = (half circumference) × length = (πr)×L. Compute π×0.92×3.10 = π×2.852 = 8.959822... so rounded to two decimals is 8.96 m^2.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Surface area = rectangular top (length×diameter) + curved half-cylinder lateral (½ of 2πrL = πrL) + two semicircular ends (2×½πr^2 = πr^2). With r=0.92 m and L=2.49 m: top = 2.49·(2·0.92)=4.5816, lateral = π·0.92·2.49≈7.1971, ends = π·0.92^2≈2.6590; sum ≈14.4377 m^2.

area.orig_question:
As shown in the figure, in the sector OAB with a radius of 1.0 and a central angle of 90.0, OA and OB are the diameters respectively as a semicircle, and the area of the shaded part in the figure is ()
Choices:

area.new_question_description: The radius of the sector is increased from 1.0 to 2.0 while keeping the quarter‑circle sector and the two semicircles on OA and OB; compute the shaded area for the larger figure.
area.new_question: In the sector OAB with radius 2.0 and central angle 90°, where OA and OB serve as diameters for semicircles drawn inside the sector as in the figure, what is the area of the shaded region? A. 2 B. π/2 − 1 C. π/4 D. 1/2
area.new_answer_description: The shaded area scales with the square of the radius. For radius 1 the shaded area is 1/2; scaling by factor 2 in radius multiplies area by 2^2=4, so shaded area = 4*(1/2) = 2.
area.check_answer_description: Quarter-circle area = pi. Each semicircle has area pi/2 so their sum = pi; their overlap = area of intersection of two unit circles with center distance sqrt(2). Intersection = 2*(arccos(d/2))/1 - (d/2)*sqrt(4-d^2) = 2*(pi/4) -1 = pi/2 - 1, which is the shaded region.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Quarter-circle area = π(1)^2/4 = π/4. Each semicircle with diameter 1 has area (1/2)π(1/2)^2 = π/8, so both semicircles together occupy π/4. The shaded region shown equals the remaining area inside the sector after removing the two semicircles and adding back the small central lens (which cancels out), yielding a numeric area 1/2. (Calculations simplify to 1/2.)

area.orig_question: Write an equation for the surface area of the above cylinder if the length is $L$, the major radius $R$ and minor radius $r$. You must factorise this expression fully.

area.orig_question: In the figure above, PQRS is a rectangle. The area of triangle RST is 7 and PT=2/5*PS. What is the area of PQRS?
area.new_question_description: Changed the given ratio to PT = 1/4 * PS and changed the area of triangle RST to 6, so the rectangle area becomes an integer.
area.new_question: In the figure above, PQRS is a rectangle. The area of triangle RST is 6 and PT = 1/4 * PS. What is the area of PQRS?
area.new_answer_description: Let PS = w and PQ = h. Triangle RST has base ST = (1 - 1/4)w = (3/4)w and height h, so its area is (1/2)*(3/4)w*h = 6. Thus w*h = 2*6 / (3/4) = 12 * (4/3) = 16, which is the area of PQRS.
area.check_answer_description: Let width = PS = w and height = RS = h. PT = w/4 so ST = 3w/4. Area(ΔRST) = 1/2 * ST * h = 1/2*(3w/4)*h = (3/8)wh = 6, so wh = 6*(8/3)=16 which is area of rectangle PQRS.
area.orig_answer_description_check: Let width PS = w and height RS = h. PT = (2/5)w so ST = (3/5)w. Area triangle RST = (1/2)*h*ST = (1/2)*h*(3/5)w = 7, so h*w*(3/10)=7 ⇒ h*w = 7*(10/3)=70/3. Rectangle area = h*w = 70/3.

area.orig_question:
Find the surface area of the following solid prism. The right rectangle surface has one edge of 10cm.

area.new_question: In the pictured oblique prism, the base horizontal length is 15 cm, the left vertical edge is 12 cm and the right vertical edge is 4 cm; what is the length y of the slanted top edge?
area.new_answer_description: The slanted edge y is the hypotenuse of a right triangle whose horizontal leg is the base 15 cm and whose vertical leg is the difference in vertical heights: 12 − 4 = 8 cm. So y = sqrt(15^2 + 8^2) = sqrt(225 + 64) = sqrt(289) = 17.
area.check_answer_description: The top edge connects the top of the left and right verticals separated horizontally by 15 cm and vertically by 12−4=8 cm, so use Pythagoras: y = sqrt(15^2+8^2) = sqrt(225+64) = sqrt(289) = 17 cm.
area.orig_answer_description_check: The top slanted edge forms the hypotenuse of a right triangle with horizontal run 13 cm and vertical drop 10−3 = 7 cm, so y = sqrt(13^2 + 7^2) = sqrt(169+49) = sqrt(218). Compute to one decimal place.

expression.orig_question:
What could be the equation of the polynomial function p?
Choices:
A:p(x)=x(x-3)^2(2 x+7)
B:p(x)=x^2(x-3)(2 x+7)
C:p(x)=x(x-3)^2(2 x+7)^2
D:p(x)=x(x-3)(2 x+7)^2
expression.new_question_description: Change the multiplicities of the roots so that x=0 is now a double root (touches the x-axis) and x=3 is a simple root (crosses the x-axis), keeping the other root at x = -7/2 and the end behavior upward on both ends.
expression.new_question:
Which of the following could be the equation of the polynomial function p if it has a double root at x=0, simple roots at x=3 and x=-7/2, and rises to +∞ as x → ±∞?
A. x(x-3)(2x+7)^2
B. p(x)=x^2(x-3)(2x+7)
C. -x^2(x-3)(2x+7)
D. x^2(x-3)^2(2x+7)
expression.new_answer_description: Roots and multiplicities give factors x^2 (for double root at 0), (x-3) (simple root at 3), and (2x+7) (root at x = -7/2). Multiplying these gives p(x)=x^2(x-3)(2x+7); the leading term is positive so end behavior is up on both ends.
expression.check_answer_description: Double root at 0 gives factor x^2, simple roots at 3 and -7/2 give factors (x-3) and (2x+7); degree 4 with positive leading coefficient (e.g. 2) yields +∞ as x→±∞ so p(x)=x^2(x-3)(2x+7) works.
expression.orig_answer_description_check: Roots at x=0, x=3, and x=-7/2 are visible. At x=0 the graph crosses (odd multiplicity → power 1), at x=3 it touches and turns (even multiplicity → squared), and at x=-7/2 it crosses (odd multiplicity → power 1). Thus factorization x*(x-3)^2*(2x+7) fits.

expression.orig_question: Function f in blue is a parabola as $y=x^2$. Function g in red can be thought of as a scaled version of f(x)=x^2. Write the equation for g(x).

expression.orig_answer_description_check: g is of form g(x)=a x^2; use point (2,3): 3 = a*(2^2) = 4a, so a = 3/4; hence g(x) = (3/4)x^2.

expression.orig_question: Find the equation of the dashed line. Use exact numbers.

expression.check_answer_description: Use vertex form y = a(x-h)^2 + k with (h,k)=(0,-1): y = a x^2 -1. Substitute (2,-4): -4 = 4a -1 → 4a = -3 → a = -3/4. So equation is y = (-3/4)x^2 - 1.

expression.new_answer_description: As x→∞ the graph rises to +∞ and as x→−∞ it falls to −∞, which is characteristic of an odd-degree polynomial. The right end rising indicates the leading coefficient is positive. Therefore p has odd degree and a positive leading coefficient.

volume.check_answer_description: Use sphere volume formula V = (4/3)πr^3 with r = 3 cm: V = (4/3)π(3^3) = (4/3)π(27) = 36π ≈ 113.10 cm^3.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: The diagram shows a sphere with radius 4 cm. Volume formula V = (4/3)πr^3. Compute V = (4/3)π(4^3) = (4/3)π(64) = (256/3)π ≈ 268.08 cm^3.

volume.orig_question:
Find the volume of the cone pictured here. The radius is 4.1 centimeters.

(Give your answer correct to 1 decimal place.)
volume.new_question_description: Change the cone's radius and height to new values while keeping the same figure; compute the new cone volume to one decimal place.
volume.new_question: Find the volume of the cone pictured here if the radius is 3.8 centimeters and the height is 14.2 centimeters. (Give your answer correct to 1 decimal place.)
volume.new_answer_description: Volume of a cone = (1/3)πr^2h. Compute r^2 = 3.8^2 = 14.44. Multiply by height: 14.44 × 14.2 = 205.048. Divide by 3: 205.048 / 3 = 68.349333... Multiply by π: 68.349333... × π ≈ 214.715. Rounded to one decimal place gives 214.7.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Volume = (1/3)πr^2h. Compute r^2 = 4.1^2 = 16.81. Multiply by h: 16.81×12.5 = 210.125. Multiply by π/3: V = (210.125π)/3 ≈ 220.0 cm^3 (to one decimal).

volume.orig_question: The solid in the figure is constructed by 3 segments, 2 of segments are same cylinder on each side of the solid with radius of 11. The cylinder in the middle has radius of 4. Calculate the volume of the solid. Round your answer to one decimal place.
volume.new_question_description: The middle cylinder's diameter is increased from 4 to 6 and its length is changed from 7 to 9 while the two identical end cylinders remain with radius 11 and length 8 each.
volume.new_question: The solid is formed by three coaxial cylinders: two identical end cylinders each of radius 11 and length 8, and a middle cylinder of diameter 6 and length 9; what is the total volume of the solid? Round to one decimal place.
volume.new_answer_description: Volume = sum of volumes of three cylinders. End cylinders: 2 * (π * 11^2 * 8) = 2 * (π * 121 * 8) = 1936π. Middle cylinder: π * 3^2 * 9 = 81π. Total = (1936 + 81)π = 2017π ≈ 2017 * 3.14159265 = 6336.2.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Volume = 2*(volume of each end cylinder) + (volume of middle cylinder). Each end: π*(11^2)*8 = 968π, middle: π*(4^2)*7 = 112π. Total = (2*968π + 112π) = 2048π ≈ 6434.0.

volume.orig_question:
The diameter is 3 centimeters.

Find the volume of the solid, correct to two decimal places.
volume.new_question_description: The semicircular base diameter is increased from 3 cm to 4 cm; keep the slant length from the semicircle edge to the apex as 9 cm and ask for the volume.
volume.new_question: The diameter is 4 centimeters. Find the volume of the solid, correct to two decimal places.
volume.new_answer_description: Radius r = 4/2 = 2 cm. Height h is found from the right triangle: h = sqrt(9^2 - 2^2) = sqrt(77) ≈ 8.774964. Area of the semicircular base = (1/2)πr^2 = (1/2)π(4) = 2π. Volume = (1/3) × base area × height = (1/3)(2π)(h) = (2π/3)h ≈ (2π/3)(8.774964) ≈ 18.39.
volume.check_answer_description: Radius = 4/2 = 2 cm. Height h = sqrt(9^2 - 2^2) = sqrt(77). Volume = (1/3)πr^2h = (4π/3)·sqrt(77). Evaluate ≈ 36.74 cm^3.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Treat base as a semicircle of diameter 3 cm so r =1.5 cm. Volume of a cone-like solid = (1/3)*(area of base)*height; area of semicircular base = (1/2)πr^2. Height h = sqrt(9^2 - r^2) = sqrt(81 - 2.25) = sqrt(78.75) ≈ 8.874. Thus V = (1/3)*(1/2)πr^2*h = (π/6)·(1.5^2)·8.874 ≈ 10.45 cm^3.

volume.new_question: Given the solid with base length 10 cm and apex height 9 cm, find the volume of the solid.
volume.new_answer_description: The triangular base has area 100 cm^2 (consistent with the base dimensions shown). Volume of a pyramid = (1/3) * base area * height = (1/3) * 100 * 9 = 300 cm^3.
volume.check_answer_description: Treating the solid as a pyramid with square base side 10 cm and apex height 9 cm, volume = (1/3)×(base area)×height = (1/3)×10^2×9 = 300 cm^3.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Assume the base is an equilateral triangle of side 10 cm so its area = (sqrt(3)/4)*10^2. The pyramid height is 6 cm (given). Volume = (1/3)*(base area)*height = (1/3)*(sqrt(3)/4*100)*6 = 100*sqrt(3)/2 = 50*sqrt(3) ≈ 86.6 cm^3.

volume.new_question: Using the dimensions shown (bottom base 16 cm, top base 9 cm, trapezoid height 2 cm, and prism length 12 cm), what is the volume of the prism?
volume.new_answer_description: Area of trapezoidal cross-section = ((16 + 9)/2) * 2 = 25 cm^2. Volume = area * length = 25 * 12 = 300 cm^3.

volume.orig_question:
The weight of an empty glass jar is 250g. The height (h) is 26 cm.

Calculate its total weight when it is filled with water, correct to 2 decimal places.
volume.new_question_description: Change the jar height to 30 cm and the empty jar weight to 500 g while keeping the top radius shown (15 cm); ask for total weight when filled with water to 2 decimal places.
volume.new_question: The weight of an empty glass jar is 500 g. The top radius is 15 cm and the height (h) is 30 cm. Calculate its total weight when it is filled with water, correct to 2 decimal places.
volume.new_answer_description: Volume = πr^2h = π*(15^2)*30 = π*225*30 = π*6750 ≈ 21205.80 cm^3 so water mass ≈ 21205.80 g = 21.20580 kg. Add empty jar 0.500 kg gives total ≈ 21.70580 kg, rounded to 2 d.p. = 21.71.
volume.check_answer_description: Volume = πr^2h = π·15^2·30 = 6750π cm^3; water mass = volume (1 g/cm^3) = 6750π g ≈ 21205.75 g; add empty jar 500 g → total = 500 + 6750π ≈ 21705.75 g.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Treat the jar as a cylinder with diameter 15 cm so radius r = 7.5 cm. Volume = πr^2h = π*(7.5)^2*26 = π*56.25*26 = π*1462.5 ≈ 4594.05 cm^3. Water mass = volume (1 g/cm^3) ≈ 4594.05 g. Add empty jar 250 g to get total ≈ 4594.05 + 250 = 4844.05 g.

volume.check_answer_description: Use V = πr^2h; with r = 4 and h = 10, V = π*(4^2)*10 = 160π; compute numerically and round to two decimals.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Volume V = πr^2h; substitute r=3 and h=13: V = π(3^2)(13) = 117π; compute numeric value and round to two decimals.

volume.orig_question:

Calculate its total weight when it is filled with water, correct to 2 decimal places.

volume.new_question: The empty cylindrical glass jar weighs 250 g, has radius 15 cm and height 30 cm; what is its total weight when it is three-quarters filled with water? (Give answer correct to 2 decimal places.)
volume.new_answer_description: Volume of water = πr^2h_filled where h_filled = (3/4)*30 = 22.5 cm. So V = π*(15^2)*22.5 = π*225*22.5 = π*5062.5 ≈ 15909.96 cm^3. Mass of water ≈ 15909.96 g = 15.90996 kg. Add jar mass 0.25 kg gives total ≈ 16.15996 kg ≈ 16.16 kg.
volume.check_answer_description: Compute water volume = πr^2h with r=15 cm and h=0.75·30=22.5 cm: V=π·15^2·22.5=5062.5π ≈15904.31284 cm^3 → water mass ≈15904.31 g (1 cm^3 =1 g). Add jar mass 250 g → total =250+15904.31=16154.31 g.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Volume = πr^2h with r=15 cm and h=26 cm → V = π(15^2)(26)=5850π cm^3 ≈5850 g of water; add jar 250 g → total = 5850+250 = 6100 g.

volume.new_question: Two similar solids as shown in the figure, the larger solid has volume 9000 cm^3. Find the fully simplified ratio of the volume of the larger solid to the volume of the smaller solid.
volume.new_answer_description: Divide the larger volume by the smaller volume: 9000 ÷ 90 = 100.
volume.check_answer_description: Volumes ratio = larger volume ÷ smaller volume = 9000 ÷ 90 = 100, so the volume ratio is 100:1.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Volumes ratio = larger volume ÷ smaller volume = 5760 ÷ 90 = 64, so the larger : smaller = 64 : 1.

volume.orig_question: The radius of solid figure in figure is 5 centimeters. Find the volume of the figure shown, correct to two decimal places.

volume.new_question: The radius of the solid figure in the figure is 6 centimeters. Find the volume of the figure shown, correct to two decimal places.
volume.new_answer_description: For this solid the volume scales with the square of the radius (area of cross-section scales as r^2) while length/shape stay the same. Using the original volume for r = 5 cm (883.57 cm^3), scale by (6/5)^2 = 1.44: V = 883.57 × 1.44 = 1272.34 cm^3 (rounded to two decimals).
volume.check_answer_description: Volume = volume of full cylinder (radius 6, length 15) minus volume of semicylindrical cutout (radius 5, length 15): V = π(6^2)(15) - (1/2)π(5^2)(15) = π·15(36 - 12.5) = 352.5π ≈ 1107.41 cm^3.
volume.orig_answer_description_check: Treat the solid as a capsule: a cylinder of radius r=5 and height h=15 plus two hemispheres (together a sphere) of radius 5. Volume = π r^2 h + (4/3)π r^3 = π(25)(15) + (4/3)π(125) = (1625/3)π. Numerically (1625/3)π ≈ 1701.70 cm^3.

volume.orig_question: Calculate the volume of the half cylinder correct to one decimal place. The height is 9 cm and diameter is 6 cm.

volume.new_question: Calculate the volume of the half cylinder correct to one decimal place if the height is 12 cm and the diameter is 8 cm.
volume.new_answer_description: Radius = 8/2 = 4 cm. Full cylinder volume = πr^2h = π(4^2)(12) = 192π. Half-cylinder volume = (1/2)*192π = 96π ≈ 96 × 3.14159265 = 301.5929, which rounds to 301.6.
volume.check_answer_description: Half-cylinder volume = (1/2)·πr^2h with r=8/2=4 and h=12, so V=(1/2)·π·4^2·12=(1/2)·π·192=96π ≈ 301.5929; rounded to one decimal is 301.6.

volume.orig_question:
The length is 13 centimeters.

The pipe is made of a particularly strong metal.

Calculate the weight of the pipe if 1 (cm)^3 of the metal weighs 5.3g , giving your answer correct to one decimal place.
volume.new_question_description: Change the pipe length from 13 cm to 15 cm and ask for the new weight (same diameters and density as in the image).
volume.new_question: The pipe is 15 cm long; calculate its weight if 1 cm^3 of the metal weighs 5.3 g, giving your answer correct to one decimal place.
volume.new_answer_description: Cross-sectional area of metal = π(1.05^2 − 0.9^2) = π(0.2925) ≈ 0.91895 cm^2. Volume = area × length = 0.91895 × 15 ≈ 13.7843 cm^3. Weight = volume × density = 13.7843 × 5.3 ≈ 73.074 g, rounded to one decimal place gives 73.1 g.
volume.check_answer_description: Compute cross-sectional area = π( (2.1/2)^2 - (1.8/2)^2 ) = π(1.1025-0.81)=0.2925π cm^2. Volume = area×15 = 4.3875π cm^3. Mass = volume×5.3 = 5.3×4.3875π ≈ 73.0 g (to 1 d.p.).
